elements.content: Energy-efficient solid-state-lighting (SSL) technologies are rapidly developing, but the lack of stable, high-performance rare-earth free phosphors may impede the growth of the SSL market. One possible alternative is organic phosphor materials, but these can suffer from lower quantum yields and thermal instability compared to rare-earth phosphors. However, if luminescent organic chromophores can be built into a rigid metal–organic framework, their quantum yields and thermal stability can be greatly improved. This Forum Article discusses the design of a group of such chromophore-based luminescent metal–organic frameworks with exceptionally high performance and rational control of the important parameters that influence their emission properties, including electronic structures of chromophore, coligands, metal ions, and guest molecules.
elements.clean_text: Energy-efficient solid-state-lighting (SSL) technologies are rapidly developing, but the lack of stable, high-performance rare-earth free phosphors may impede the growth of the SSL market. One possible alternative is organic phosphor materials, but these can suffer from lower quantum yields and thermal instability compared to rare-earth phosphors. However, if luminescent organic chromophores can be built into a rigid metal-organic framework, their quantum yields and thermal stability can be greatly improved. This Forum Article discusses the design of a group of such chromophore-based luminescent metal-organic frameworks with exceptionally high performance and rational control of the important parameters that influence their emission properties, including electronic structures of chromophore, coligands, metal ions, and guest molecules.

elements.content: We discuss the rational design of highly efficient luminescent metal−organic frameworks (LMOFs) by immobilizing strongly emissive chromophores in their structures. This process presents a new approach to significantly improving their luminescence quantum yield and thermal stability and systematically tuning their emission energy and color through the inclusion of secondary ligands or guest molecules. The exceptionally high performance of these LMOFs makes them promising candidates as rare-earth free phosphors for energy-efficient lighting applications.
elements.clean_text: We discuss the rational design of highly efficient luminescent metal-organic frameworks (LMOFs) by immobilizing strongly emissive chromophores in their structures. This process presents a new approach to significantly improving their luminescence quantum yield and thermal stability and systematically tuning their emission energy and color through the inclusion of secondary ligands or guest molecules. The exceptionally high performance of these LMOFs makes them promising candidates as rare-earth free phosphors for energy-efficient lighting applications.

elements.content: As global awareness of the importance of energy efficiency has increased, solid-state-lighting (SSL) devices have been rapidly adopted because of their low power usage and long lifetimes. According to the 2015 U.S. Department of Energy SSL Research & Development Plan, light-emitting-diode (LED)-based bulbs made up only 5% of global sales in 2014 but are expected to comprise 42% of global sales by 2020. In the United States, it is estimated that 88% of all general lighting devices will be LED-based by 2030, saving between 260 and 395 TWh of energy annually. To provide some perspective, that is almost twice the projected 2030 annual electrical energy output for wind and solar energy combined.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

As global awareness of the importance of energy efficiency has increased, solid-state-lighting (SSL) devices have been rapidly adopted because of their low power usage and long lifetimes. According to the 2015 U.S. Department of Energy SSL Research & Development Plan, light-emitting-diode (LED)-based bulbs made up only 5% of global sales in 2014 but are expected to comprise 42% of global sales by 2020. In the United States, it is estimated that 88% of all general lighting devices will be LED-based by 2030, saving between 260 and 395 TWh of energy annually. To provide some perspective, that is almost twice the projected 2030 annual electrical energy output for wind and solar energy combined.

elements.content: Currently, most white LEDs fall into two categories: multichip white LEDs (MC-WLEDs), in which white light is created by mixing emissions from red, green, and blue LED chips, or phosphor-converted white LEDs (PC-WLEDs), in which white light is created by mixing emission from a blue or UV LED chip with emission from yellow or red/green/blue phosphors, respectively. Because of their relative simplicity, blue/yellow PC-WLEDs are the most efficient. A cerium­(III)-doped yttrium–aluminum garnet (YAG:Ce) is the most commonly used yellow phosphor in these PC-WLEDs, but this presents a challenge. The global supply of yttrium is projected to remain at a deficit relative to demand until beyond 2020, and more than 99% of worldwide yttrium deposits are located in China. As the demand for yttrium and other rare-earth metals increases, new rare-earth free phosphor materials must be developed in order to reach projected LED adoption levels.
elements.clean_text: Currently, most white LEDs fall into two categories: multichip white LEDs (MC-WLEDs), in which white light is created by mixing emissions from red, green, and blue LED chips, or phosphor-converted white LEDs (PC-WLEDs), in which white light is created by mixing emission from a blue or UV LED chip with emission from yellow or red/green/blue phosphors, respectively. Because of their relative simplicity, blue/yellow PC-WLEDs are the most efficient. A cerium(III)-doped yttrium-aluminum garnet (YAG:Ce) is the most commonly used yellow phosphor in these PC-WLEDs, but this presents a challenge. The global supply of yttrium is projected to remain at a deficit relative to demand until beyond 2020, and more than 99% of worldwide yttrium deposits are located in China. As the demand for yttrium and other rare-earth metals increases, new rare-earth free phosphor materials must be developed in order to reach projected LED adoption levels.

elements.content: Organic phosphors are one possible alternative, although yellow- and red-emitting organic chromophores typically suffer from lower quantum yields (QYs) and thermal instability compared to rare-earth phosphors such as YAG:Ce. One way to address this challenge is to construct robust structures by incorporating these organic chromophores into metal–organic frameworks (MOFs).
elements.clean_text: Organic phosphors are one possible alternative, although yellow- and red-emitting organic chromophores typically suffer from lower quantum yields (QYs) and thermal instability compared to rare-earth phosphors such as YAG:Ce. One way to address this challenge is to construct robust structures by incorporating these organic chromophores into metal-organic frameworks (MOFs).

elements.content: MOFs are structures built of single metal ions (primary building units or PBUs) or metal-ion clusters (secondary building units or SBUs) that are linked together in an ordered fashion by organic ligands. Many MOFs exhibit permanent porosity, and their chemical and physical properties can be tuned by altering the metal ion(s) or organic ligand(s) that they are composed of. Because of their easy-to-functionalize pore surfaces and diverse structures, MOFs are being investigated for a variety of applications, including gas storage and separation, catalysis, and sensing.
elements.clean_text: MOFs are structures built of single metal ions (primary building units or PBUs) or metal-ion clusters (secondary building units or SBUs) that are linked together in an ordered fashion by organic ligands. Many MOFs exhibit permanent porosity, and their chemical and physical properties can be tuned by altering the metal ion(s) or organic ligand(s) that they are composed of. Because of their easy-to-functionalize pore surfaces and diverse structures, MOFs are being investigated for a variety of applications, including gas storage and separation, catalysis, and sensing.

elements.content: Our strategy to develop organic chromophore-based MOFs is centered on the following consideration: By using chromophoric ligands in the synthesis, highly luminescent metal–organic frameworks (LMOFs) can be constructed that can not only maintain the emission from their ligands but also enhance and tune their emission properties. LMOF QYs can be higher than their chromophoric ligands because their rigid structures limit the molecular vibrations, torsions, and rotations that often lead to nonradiative excitation decay in the molecular chromophore. In addition, binding chromophores into a rigid framework can improve their thermal stability. Third, including a second ligand in the framework construction may contribute to fine-tuning of the emission energy and color. Finally, because many MOFs are porous, it also provides an opportunity to tailor the chromophore emission via host–guest interactions.
elements.clean_text: Our strategy to develop organic chromophore-based MOFs is centered on the following consideration: By using chromophoric ligands in the synthesis, highly luminescent metal-organic frameworks (LMOFs) can be constructed that can not only maintain the emission from their ligands but also enhance and tune their emission properties. LMOF QYs can be higher than their chromophoric ligands because their rigid structures limit the molecular vibrations, torsions, and rotations that often lead to nonradiative excitation decay in the molecular chromophore. In addition, binding chromophores into a rigid framework can improve their thermal stability. Third, including a second ligand in the framework construction may contribute to fine-tuning of the emission energy and color. Finally, because many MOFs are porous, it also provides an opportunity to tailor the chromophore emission via host-guest interactions.

elements.content: In order to design a high-performing LMOF, we began by selecting a strongly emissive organic chromophore that could be functionalized with carboxylate groups to provide binding sites for its eventual construction into a framework structure. Our starting point was the chromophore tetraphenylethene (tpe), which is well-known to fluoresce through aggregation-induced emission (AIE). An AIE chromophore was initially chosen because it was known that restricting the molecular movement available to the chromophore would result in markedly improved luminescent efficiency (such a restriction should occur upon incorporation into a framework); however, this process is generalizable to non-AIE chromophores as well.
elements.clean_text:
Overview of LMOF Design and Synthesis

LMOF-231

In order to design a high-performing LMOF, we began by selecting a strongly emissive organic chromophore that could be functionalized with carboxylate groups to provide binding sites for its eventual construction into a framework structure. Our starting point was the chromophore tetraphenylethene (tpe), which is well-known to fluoresce through aggregation-induced emission (AIE). An AIE chromophore was initially chosen because it was known that restricting the molecular movement available to the chromophore would result in markedly improved luminescent efficiency (such a restriction should occur upon incorporation into a framework); however, this process is generalizable to non-AIE chromophores as well.

elements.content: One drawback of using tpe as the chromophore in constructing an LMOF is its high emission energy. As described above a blue-excitable, yellow-emitting LMOF would be preferable for use in PC-WLEDs, and the chromophore emission should be consistent with that goal. In order to shift the emission into the yellow region, DFT calculations (see S2) were performed to estimate the impact of structural changes to the tetracarboxylated tpe chromophore tetrakis­(4-carboxyphenyl)­ethylene (H4tcpe) on its emission energy (). These calculations indicated that the extension of each H4tcpe arm by an additional phenyl ring should red-shift the molecule’s emission energy. This led to the synthesis of a yellow chromophore, 1,1,2,2-tetrakis­(4-(4-carboxy-phenyl)­phenyl)­ethene (H4tcbpe; ). As desired, H4tcbpe exhibits a strong yellow emission at 540 nm, with a high QY of 70.3% under 365 nm excitation ().
elements.clean_text: One drawback of using tpe as the chromophore in constructing an LMOF is its high emission energy. As described above a blue-excitable, yellow-emitting LMOF would be preferable for use in PC-WLEDs, and the chromophore emission should be consistent with that goal. In order to shift the emission into the yellow region, DFT calculations (see S2) were performed to estimate the impact of structural changes to the tetracarboxylated tpe chromophore tetrakis(4-carboxyphenyl)ethylene (H4tcpe) on its emission energy (). These calculations indicated that the extension of each H4tcpe arm by an additional phenyl ring should red-shift the molecule's emission energy. This led to the synthesis of a yellow chromophore, 1,1,2,2-tetrakis(4-(4-carboxy-phenyl)phenyl)ethene (H4tcbpe; ). As desired, H4tcbpe exhibits a strong yellow emission at 540 nm, with a high QY of 70.3% under 365 nm excitation ().

The peak emission and excitation intensities are scaled to internal QYs. Reproduced from ref . Copyright 2015 Royal Society of Chemistry.

elements.content: Finally, in the design of a LMOF with chromophore-based emission, it was important that the metal ions used in constructing the framework do not interfere with the chromophore’s optical properties. The Zn2+ ion was chosen for this purpose because density of states calculations indicate that the fully occupied 3d subshell lies far below the valence band region, preventing the metal ion from participating in MOF luminescence (see S2 and Figure S2).
elements.clean_text: Finally, in the design of a LMOF with chromophore-based emission, it was important that the metal ions used in constructing the framework do not interfere with the chromophore's optical properties. The Zn2+ ion was chosen for this purpose because density of states calculations indicate that the fully occupied 3d subshell lies far below the valence band region, preventing the metal ion from participating in MOF luminescence (see S2 and Figure S2).

elements.content: LMOF-231, with the formula Zn2(tcbpe)·xDMA (1), was synthesized in solvothermal conditions; 0.3 mmol of Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O reacted with 0.03 mmol of H4tcbpe in 2 mL of dimethylacetamide (DMA) at 120 °C for 48 h. The residual solvent molecules were then removed by heating under vacuum at 100 °C overnight to give 1′, with structural stability confirmed via powder X-ray diffraction (XRD; see S6 and Figure S4). The structure is composed of an infinite zinc carboxylate PBU running in the c direction, with stacked columns of tcbpe molecules bridging four zinc carboxylate chains. The zinc ions are tetrahedrally coordinated, with two carboxylates bridging between each Zn2+ ion and its two neighboring ions. The tcbpe layers are closely packed, with interlayer H–H distances between 2.4 and 3.2 Å ().
elements.clean_text: LMOF-231, with the formula Zn2(tcbpe)⋅xDMA (1), was synthesized in solvothermal conditions; 0.3 mmol of Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O reacted with 0.03 mmol of H4tcbpe in 2 mL of dimethylacetamide (DMA) at 120 °C for 48 h. The residual solvent molecules were then removed by heating under vacuum at 100 °C overnight to give 1', with structural stability confirmed via powder X-ray diffraction (XRD; see S6 and Figure S4). The structure is composed of an infinite zinc carboxylate PBU running in the c direction, with stacked columns of tcbpe molecules bridging four zinc carboxylate chains. The zinc ions are tetrahedrally coordinated, with two carboxylates bridging between each Zn2+ ion and its two neighboring ions. The tcbpe layers are closely packed, with interlayer H-H distances between 2.4 and 3.2 Å ().

elements.content: 1′ has exceptional optical properties; its performance clearly demonstrates the value of incorporating the H4tcbpe chromophore into a MOF. With the H4tcbpe’s desirable emission energy maintained and only a slight red shift to 550 nm, immobilization of the molecule enforced by the framework increased the internal QY from 70.3% under 365 nm excitation for the bulk chromophore to 82.5% for the solvated framework 1 by preventing phenyl ring rotation and CC bond torsion at the central ethene moiety, which dominate nonradiative excitation decay pathways in tpe-based chromophores. Outgassing to yield 1′ eliminates emission quenching due the solvent molecules, further increasing the internal QY to 95.1% under 365 nm excitation and 76.4% under 455 nm excitation, which is competitive with the commercial phosphor YAG:Ce ().
elements.clean_text: 1' has exceptional optical properties; its performance clearly demonstrates the value of incorporating the H4tcbpe chromophore into a MOF. With the H4tcbpe's desirable emission energy maintained and only a slight red shift to 550 nm, immobilization of the molecule enforced by the framework increased the internal QY from 70.3% under 365 nm excitation for the bulk chromophore to 82.5% for the solvated framework 1 by preventing phenyl ring rotation and CC bond torsion at the central ethene moiety, which dominate nonradiative excitation decay pathways in tpe-based chromophores. Outgassing to yield 1' eliminates emission quenching due the solvent molecules, further increasing the internal QY to 95.1% under 365 nm excitation and 76.4% under 455 nm excitation, which is competitive with the commercial phosphor YAG:Ce ().

elements.content: In addition to improving the chromophore’s optical qualities, incorporating H4tcbpe into a MOF significantly enhanced its thermal stability, as indicated by thermogravimetric analysis (TGA; see S7 and Figure S7). While molecular H4tcbpe began to decompose around 340 °C, 1′ remained thermally stable until about 450 °C.
elements.clean_text: In addition to improving the chromophore's optical qualities, incorporating H4tcbpe into a MOF significantly enhanced its thermal stability, as indicated by thermogravimetric analysis (TGA; see S7 and Figure S7). While molecular H4tcbpe began to decompose around 340 °C, 1' remained thermally stable until about 450 °C.

elements.content: In addition to carboxylate-based chromophores like H4tcbpe, chromophores with appropriately positioned pyridine groups (and other nitrogen-based groups) can also be incorporated into LMOFs. However, in order to construct a neutral framework using a pyridine-based ligand, a secondary carboxylate-based ligand is needed for charge balancing. We constructed an example of this type of LMOF using the pyridine derivative of H4tcbpe, which is 1,1,2,2-tetrakis­[4-(pyridin-4-yl)­phenyl]­ethene (tppe; ), synthesized according to a method that we reported. Bulk tppe emits at 490 nm under 340 nm excitation, with an internal QY of 76.7%. The secondary carboxylate ligand chosen for this structure is 1,1′-biphenyl-4,4′-dicarboxylic acid (bpdc). As in the previous case and for the same reasons, the Zn2+ ion was used to immobilize tppe and bpdc in a rigid framework.
elements.clean_text:
LMOF-241

In addition to carboxylate-based chromophores like H4tcbpe, chromophores with appropriately positioned pyridine groups (and other nitrogen-based groups) can also be incorporated into LMOFs. However, in order to construct a neutral framework using a pyridine-based ligand, a secondary carboxylate-based ligand is needed for charge balancing. We constructed an example of this type of LMOF using the pyridine derivative of H4tcbpe, which is 1,1,2,2-tetrakis[4-(pyridin-4-yl)phenyl]ethene (tppe; ), synthesized according to a method that we reported. Bulk tppe emits at 490 nm under 340 nm excitation, with an internal QY of 76.7%. The secondary carboxylate ligand chosen for this structure is 1,1'-biphenyl-4,4'-dicarboxylic acid (bpdc). As in the previous case and for the same reasons, the Zn2+ ion was used to immobilize tppe and bpdc in a rigid framework.

elements.content: (a) Structure of the chromophore tppe. (b) Tetrahedral Zn2+ ion, bpdc coligand in gray, and tppe in gold combining to form the PBU. (c) Structure of a single LMOF-241 framework, with hexagonal channels running along the c axis. (d) Three distinct LMOF-241 frameworks that interpenetrate to form the complete structure. Color key: C, gray or gold; N, blue; O, red; Zn, aqua. Reprinted with permission from ref . Copyright 2015 American Chemical Society.

(c) Structure of a single LMOF-241 framework, with hexagonal channels running along the c axis. (d) Three distinct LMOF-241 frameworks that interpenetrate to form the complete structure. Color key: C, gray or gold; N, blue; O, red; Zn, aqua. Reprinted with permission from ref . Copyright 2015 American Chemical Society.

elements.content: LMOF-241 (2), with the formula Zn2(bpdc)2(tppe)·sol (sol = solvent molecules), was synthesized in solvothermal conditions, with 0.05 mmol of Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O reacting with 0.02 mmol of tppe and 0.05 mmol of bpdc in 12 mL of 4:1:1 DMA/dismethyl sulfoxide/isopropyl alcohol at 150 °C for 24 h. Following solvent exchange with dichloromethane, the structure was outgassed under vacuum overnight at 60 °C, with powder XRD analysis used to confirm the stability of the structure following outgassing (see S6 and Figure S5). This structure is composed of three interpenetrated frameworks, with each framework consisting of tetrahedrally coordinated Zn2+ PBUs linked to its neighbors by two bridging tppe ligands and two bridging bpdc ligands. Hexagonal channels run along the c axis of each framework and remain present (although distorted) in the triply interpenetrated final structure (). As observed with 1′, emission from the chromophore tppe is preserved in 2 with only a slight red shift of 10 nm (from 490 to 500 nm), while the internal QY is increased from 76.7% to 92.7% under 340 nm excitation ().
elements.clean_text: LMOF-241 (2), with the formula Zn2(bpdc)2(tppe)⋅sol (sol = solvent molecules), was synthesized in solvothermal conditions, with 0.05 mmol of Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O reacting with 0.02 mmol of tppe and 0.05 mmol of bpdc in 12 mL of 4:1:1 DMA/dismethyl sulfoxide/isopropyl alcohol at 150 °C for 24 h. Following solvent exchange with dichloromethane, the structure was outgassed under vacuum overnight at 60 °C, with powder XRD analysis used to confirm the stability of the structure following outgassing (see S6 and Figure S5). This structure is composed of three interpenetrated frameworks, with each framework consisting of tetrahedrally coordinated Zn2+ PBUs linked to its neighbors by two bridging tppe ligands and two bridging bpdc ligands. Hexagonal channels run along the c axis of each framework and remain present (although distorted) in the triply interpenetrated final structure (). As observed with 1', emission from the chromophore tppe is preserved in 2 with only a slight red shift of 10 nm (from 490 to 500 nm), while the internal QY is increased from 76.7% to 92.7% under 340 nm excitation ().

elements.content: Excitation (dotted lines) and emission (solid lines) spectra for the tppe chromophore (red) and 2 (blue). The peak intensity is scaled to the internal QY. Reprinted with permission from ref . Copyright 2015 American Chemical Society.
elements.clean_text: 4  Excitation (dotted lines) and emission (solid lines) spectra for the tppe chromophore (red) and 2 (blue). The peak intensity is scaled to the internal QY. Reprinted with permission from ref . Copyright 2015 American Chemical Society.

elements.content: Beyond serving structural and charge-balancing needs, secondary ligands can also participate in luminescence via a ligand-to-ligand charge-transfer mechanism, presenting an opportunity to adjust the emission energy from the primary chromophore ligand. In the previous examples, we were interested in keeping the chromophore emission essentially unchanged, so the metal and coligand were chosen specifically to avoid optical interaction with the chromophore ligand. As a result, the LMOF highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO)/lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO) energy levels reflected solely those of the chromophores. However, if we use a coligand with a LUMO energy level that is lower than that of the chromophore, the LUMO of the LMOF should also be lower, resulting in red-shifted emission (). This process of band-gap modulation is especially interesting in the case of tppe because the green-emitting chromophore would have more applications if its emission could be tuned into the yellow region.
elements.clean_text:
LMOF-251

Beyond serving structural and charge-balancing needs, secondary ligands can also participate in luminescence via a ligand-to-ligand charge-transfer mechanism, presenting an opportunity to adjust the emission energy from the primary chromophore ligand. In the previous examples, we were interested in keeping the chromophore emission essentially unchanged, so the metal and coligand were chosen specifically to avoid optical interaction with the chromophore ligand. As a result, the LMOF highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO)/lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO) energy levels reflected solely those of the chromophores. However, if we use a coligand with a LUMO energy level that is lower than that of the chromophore, the LUMO of the LMOF should also be lower, resulting in red-shifted emission (). This process of band-gap modulation is especially interesting in the case of tppe because the green-emitting chromophore would have more applications if its emission could be tuned into the yellow region.

elements.content: Top: UV–vis absorption of tppe (pink, dotted) and 3 (blue, solid). The inset is a schematic demonstrating the relative positions of the HOMO/LUMO energy levels of tppe, btc, and 3 and the band-gap modulation process. Bottom: Excitation and emission spectra of the tppe chromophore (dotted) and 3 (solid), with emission spectra collected under varying excitation energies. tppe: excitation (pink) and emission under 360 nm (black), 400 nm (red), 420 nm (blue), and 440 nm (green). 3: excitation (blue, left) and emission under 360 nm (black), 400 nm (red), 420 nm (blue, right), and 440 nm (green). The inset is a schematic demonstrating the relative positions of the HOMO/LUMO energy levels of tppe, btc, and 3 and the band-gap modulation process. Bottom: Excitation and emission spectra of the tppe chromophore (dotted) and 3 (solid), with emission spectra collected under varying excitation energies. tppe: excitation (pink) and emission under 360 nm (black), 400 nm (red), 420 nm (blue), and 440 nm (green). 3: excitation (blue, left) and emission under 360 nm (black), 400 nm (red), 420 nm (blue, right), and 440 nm (green). Reprinted with permission from ref . Copyright 2014 American Chemical Society.

elements.content: To realize this emission shift, we synthesized a LMOF containing tppe and benzene-1,3,5-tricarboxylic acid (btc). DFT calculations (see S2) indicated that the LUMO of btc lies approximately 0.279 eV below that of tppe (), enabling its use as a band-gap modulator for tppe. LMOF-251 (3), with the formula Zn3(btc)2(tppe)­(DMA)·4.5DMA·6H2O, was synthesized with 0.06 mmol of Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O, 0.04 mmol of btc, 0.02 mmol of tppe, and 0.3 mL of concentrated tetrafluoroboric acid in 15 mL of DMA at 150 °C for 48 h. The resulting LMOF is comprised of two interpenetrated frameworks (d), with each framework containing both tetrahedrally coordinated zinc PBUs and zinc paddlewheel SBUs. Each of the paddlewheel SBUs contains two zinc ions bridged by four carboxylate groups from btc ligands, with a molecule of water coordinated to each zinc along the paddlewheel axis. Each paddlewheel is connected to two neighboring SBUs (one above and one below) by the remaining btc carboxylates through four PBUs, forming a chain that runs along the a axis. Each PBU is also coordinated to two tppe molecules lying in the bc plane, with each tppe linking two of these chains together ().
elements.clean_text: To realize this emission shift, we synthesized a LMOF containing tppe and benzene-1,3,5-tricarboxylic acid (btc). DFT calculations (see S2) indicated that the LUMO of btc lies approximately 0.279 eV below that of tppe (), enabling its use as a band-gap modulator for tppe. LMOF-251 (3), with the formula Zn3(btc)2(tppe)(DMA)⋅4.5DMA⋅6H2O, was synthesized with 0.06 mmol of Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O, 0.04 mmol of btc, 0.02 mmol of tppe, and 0.3 mL of concentrated tetrafluoroboric acid in 15 mL of DMA at 150 °C for 48 h. The resulting LMOF is comprised of two interpenetrated frameworks (d), with each framework containing both tetrahedrally coordinated zinc PBUs and zinc paddlewheel SBUs. Each of the paddlewheel SBUs contains two zinc ions bridged by four carboxylate groups from btc ligands, with a molecule of water coordinated to each zinc along the paddlewheel axis. Each paddlewheel is connected to two neighboring SBUs (one above and one below) by the remaining btc carboxylates through four PBUs, forming a chain that runs along the a axis. Each PBU is also coordinated to two tppe molecules lying in the bc plane, with each tppe linking two of these chains together ().

(b) Structure of a single net in 3, with large octagonal channels running along the a axis. (c) View along the a axis showing one-dimensional channels in the framework. (d) Two identical frameworks interpenetrating to form the complete structure of 3. Color key: C, gray; N, blue; O, red; Zn, aqua. Reprinted with permission from ref . elements.content: As desired, 3 emits strongly in the yellow region at 540 nm (, bottom), corresponding to a red shift of approximately 50 nm compared to the tppe chromophore (btc is not fluorescent in the visible range). The expected reduction in the band gap that is responsible for this red-shifted emission is supported by UV–vis reflectance spectroscopy, which indicates that the band gaps of tppe and 3 are approximately 2.7 and 2.4 eV, respectively (, top). To further confirm the reduced band gap of 3 compared to tppe and the role of btc in band-gap modulation, DFT calculations were used to estimate the orbital energy levels of a neutral fragment of the LMOF (see S2 and Figure S2). The HOMO energy level of 3 was calculated to be only 0.02 eV lower than that of tppe, while its LUMO was 0.23 eV lower, which trends with the experimental data. Additionally, the LUMO of 3 was calculated to be within 0.05 eV of btc’s LUMO, confirming the band-gap-modulating role of btc ().
elements.clean_text: As desired, 3 emits strongly in the yellow region at 540 nm (, bottom), corresponding to a red shift of approximately 50 nm compared to the tppe chromophore (btc is not fluorescent in the visible range). The expected reduction in the band gap that is responsible for this red-shifted emission is supported by UV-vis reflectance spectroscopy, which indicates that the band gaps of tppe and 3 are approximately 2.7 and 2.4 eV, respectively (, top). To further confirm the reduced band gap of 3 compared to tppe and the role of btc in band-gap modulation, DFT calculations were used to estimate the orbital energy levels of a neutral fragment of the LMOF (see S2 and Figure S2). The HOMO energy level of 3 was calculated to be only 0.02 eV lower than that of tppe, while its LUMO was 0.23 eV lower, which trends with the experimental data. Additionally, the LUMO of 3 was calculated to be within 0.05 eV of btc's LUMO, confirming the band-gap-modulating role of btc ().

elements.content: As in previous cases, immobilizing the chromophore greatly improved the material’s internal QY, which was increased from to 57.2% to 90.7% under 400 nm excitation. Additionally, the band-gap modulation greatly improved the ability of 3 to be excited by blue light relative to tppe (). Under 420 nm excitation, the QY improved from 40.2% in tppe to 72.9% in 3; under 450 nm excitation, the improvement was from 32.1% to 63.9%.
elements.clean_text: As in previous cases, immobilizing the chromophore greatly improved the material's internal QY, which was increased from to 57.2% to 90.7% under 400 nm excitation. Additionally, the band-gap modulation greatly improved the ability of 3 to be excited by blue light relative to tppe (). Under 420 nm excitation, the QY improved from 40.2% in tppe to 72.9% in 3; under 450 nm excitation, the improvement was from 32.1% to 63.9%.

elements.content: In order to investigate the impact of structural changes on the chromophore performance, we sought to incorporate pyridine-based coligands into structures containing the fluorinated H4tcbpe analogue, H4tcbpe-F (). Being fluorinated at the ortho position relative to the carboxylic acid group, it was hoped that the fluorine would moderately reduce the electron density on the carboxylate groups, thereby reducing the electron density available for coordination to the Zn2+ ions, making Zn2+, in turn, more amenable to coordination with the pyridine lone pair. Additionally, DFT calculations (see S2) indicated that while functionalization with fluorine would decrease the chromophore’s HOMO and LUMO energy levels, the chromophore’s HOMO/LUMO gap should be essentially unchanged (). As expected, the fluorinated ligand fluoresced at 540 nm under 455 nm excitation, which is identical with that of the nonfluorinated ligand. However, while the emission energy is unchanged, the internal QY of H4tcbpe-F is only 46.5% under 455 nm excitation compared to 62.3% for H4tcbpe. Despite this decrease, the H4tcbpe-F chromophore is still an effective model with which to study the structural effects on chromophore behavior.
elements.clean_text:
LMOF-302

In order to investigate the impact of structural changes on the chromophore performance, we sought to incorporate pyridine-based coligands into structures containing the fluorinated H4tcbpe analogue, H4tcbpe-F (). Being fluorinated at the ortho position relative to the carboxylic acid group, it was hoped that the fluorine would moderately reduce the electron density on the carboxylate groups, thereby reducing the electron density available for coordination to the Zn2+ ions, making Zn2+, in turn, more amenable to coordination with the pyridine lone pair. Additionally, DFT calculations (see S2) indicated that while functionalization with fluorine would decrease the chromophore's HOMO and LUMO energy levels, the chromophore's HOMO/LUMO gap should be essentially unchanged (). As expected, the fluorinated ligand fluoresced at 540 nm under 455 nm excitation, which is identical with that of the nonfluorinated ligand. However, while the emission energy is unchanged, the internal QY of H4tcbpe-F is only 46.5% under 455 nm excitation compared to 62.3% for H4tcbpe. Despite this decrease, the H4tcbpe-F chromophore is still an effective model with which to study the structural effects on chromophore behavior.

elements.content: (a) Zinc paddlewheel (top left), azpy coligand (bottom left), and tcbpe-F fluorophore combining to form a fragment of 4. (b) Structure of a single framework in 4, viewed along the b axis. (c) Two identical frameworks interpenetrating to form the complete structure of 4, viewed along the b (top) and c (bottom) axes. Color key: C, gray or gold; N, blue; O, red; F, green; Zn, aqua.
elements.clean_text: 7  (a) Zinc paddlewheel (top left), azpy coligand (bottom left), and tcbpe-F fluorophore combining to form a fragment of 4. (b) Structure of a single framework in 4, viewed along the b axis. (c) Two identical frameworks interpenetrating to form the complete structure of 4, viewed along the b (top) and c (bottom) axes. Color key: C, gray or gold; N, blue; O, red; F, green; Zn, aqua.

elements.content: Following the synthesis of H4tcbpe-F (see S3), the first pyridine ligand to be incorporated into a structure with H4tcbpe-F was 4,4′-azopyridine (azpy). A total of 0.05 mmol of azpy was introduced into a solution with 0.05 mmol of H4tcbpe-F and 0.10 mmol of Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O in DMA. Following 48 h at 100 °C, the nonfluorescent crystalline product LMOF-302 (4) with the formula Zn2(tcbpe-F)­(azpy) was recovered. Single-crystal X-ray analysis (see S4 and Table S1) showed that the resulting structure is formed by two interpenetrated frameworks, which are related to each other through a center of inversion. Each framework consists of the classic Zn2+ paddlewheel SBUs, in which two Zn2+ atoms are bridged by four roughly orthogonal carboxylate groups from tcbpe-F. These SBUs are each coordinated to four tcbpe-F molecules, which are, in turn, coordinated to four more SBUs (etc.), forming a two-dimensional sheet in the ac plane. These sheets are linked by pillaring azpy ligands in the c direction, which coordinate through the pyridyl nitrogen and connect each of the SBUs to those above and below ().
elements.clean_text: Following the synthesis of H4tcbpe-F (see S3), the first pyridine ligand to be incorporated into a structure with H4tcbpe-F was 4,4'-azopyridine (azpy). A total of 0.05 mmol of azpy was introduced into a solution with 0.05 mmol of H4tcbpe-F and 0.10 mmol of Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O in DMA. Following 48 h at 100 °C, the nonfluorescent crystalline product LMOF-302 (4) with the formula Zn2(tcbpe-F)(azpy) was recovered. Single-crystal X-ray analysis (see S4 and Table S1) showed that the resulting structure is formed by two interpenetrated frameworks, which are related to each other through a center of inversion. Each framework consists of the classic Zn2+ paddlewheel SBUs, in which two Zn2+ atoms are bridged by four roughly orthogonal carboxylate groups from tcbpe-F. These SBUs are each coordinated to four tcbpe-F molecules, which are, in turn, coordinated to four more SBUs (etc.), forming a two-dimensional sheet in the ac plane. These sheets are linked by pillaring azpy ligands in the c direction, which coordinate through the pyridyl nitrogen and connect each of the SBUs to those above and below ().

elements.content: As shown by TGA, 4 decomposes at approximately 330 °C, which is 120 °C lower than 1 (see S7 and Figure S7). A decrease in the thermal stability is to be expected when 1 and 4 are compared because the SBUs in 4 contain Zn–N bonds, which are relatively weaker than the Zn–O bonds that make up the entirety of ligand–metal bonds in 1. Additionally, the high degree of tcbpe π–π stacking in 1 increases its thermal stability, whereas gaps of approximately 5.7 Å separate every two layers of tcbpe-F in 4, limiting the effectiveness of the π–π stacking as a thermal stabilization mechanism.
elements.clean_text: As shown by TGA, 4 decomposes at approximately 330 °C, which is 120 °C lower than 1 (see S7 and Figure S7). A decrease in the thermal stability is to be expected when 1 and 4 are compared because the SBUs in 4 contain Zn-N bonds, which are relatively weaker than the Zn-O bonds that make up the entirety of ligand-metal bonds in 1. Additionally, the high degree of tcbpe π-π stacking in 1 increases its thermal stability, whereas gaps of approximately 5.7 Å separate every two layers of tcbpe-F in 4, limiting the effectiveness of the π-π stacking as a thermal stabilization mechanism.

elements.content: The second pyridine-based ligand to be incorporated into a structure with tcbpe-F was 1,2-bis­(4-pyridyl)­ethane (bpe). Under the same reaction conditions as 4 (but with bpe replacing azpy), the crystalline product Zn2(tcbpe-F)­(bpe)·nDMA was recovered. Powder XRD was used to confirm that the product is isoreticular with 4 (). Solvent exchange with acetone was performed to remove residual DMA from the pores, followed by outgassing under vacuum. TGA was used to confirm full removal of the solvent, giving LMOF-304 (5), with the formula Zn2(tcbpe-F)­(bpe) (see S7 and Figure S8).
elements.clean_text:
LMOF-304

The second pyridine-based ligand to be incorporated into a structure with tcbpe-F was 1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)ethane (bpe). Under the same reaction conditions as 4 (but with bpe replacing azpy), the crystalline product Zn2(tcbpe-F)(bpe)⋅nDMA was recovered. Powder XRD was used to confirm that the product is isoreticular with 4 (). Solvent exchange with acetone was performed to remove residual DMA from the pores, followed by outgassing under vacuum. TGA was used to confirm full removal of the solvent, giving LMOF-304 (5), with the formula Zn2(tcbpe-F)(bpe) (see S7 and Figure S8).

elements.content: Overlaid powder XRD patterns for 4 (red) and 5 (blue). The simulated pattern for 4 is in black.
elements.clean_text: 8  Overlaid powder XRD patterns for 4 (red) and 5 (blue). The simulated pattern for 4 is in black.

elements.content: Unlike 4, 5 is strongly luminescent, with a peak emission of 527 nm and an internal QY of 64.0% under 455 nm excitation (). This increase from 46.5% in the fluorinated chromophore H4tcbpe-F to 64% in 5 is commensurate with the increased QYs observed between H4tcbpe and 1, suggesting that the lower QY of 5 compared to that of 1 is due primarily to the lower QY of H4tcbpe-F rather than being due to some structural factor. This consistency in the face of structural differences implies that it is possible to significantly alter LMOF structures and connectivity without affecting the base chromophore luminescence. The result also suggests that introducing a coligand can alter the electronic structure and, consequently, tune the emission energy of a LMOF.
elements.clean_text: Unlike 4, 5 is strongly luminescent, with a peak emission of 527 nm and an internal QY of 64.0% under 455 nm excitation (). This increase from 46.5% in the fluorinated chromophore H4tcbpe-F to 64% in 5 is commensurate with the increased QYs observed between H4tcbpe and 1, suggesting that the lower QY of 5 compared to that of 1 is due primarily to the lower QY of H4tcbpe-F rather than being due to some structural factor. This consistency in the face of structural differences implies that it is possible to significantly alter LMOF structures and connectivity without affecting the base chromophore luminescence. The result also suggests that introducing a coligand can alter the electronic structure and, consequently, tune the emission energy of a LMOF.

elements.content: Excitation (dotted lines) and emission (solid lines) spectra for the tcbpe-F chromophore (blue) and 5 (red). The peak excitation and emission intensities are scaled to the internal QY.
elements.clean_text: 9  Excitation (dotted lines) and emission (solid lines) spectra for the tcbpe-F chromophore (blue) and 5 (red). The peak excitation and emission intensities are scaled to the internal QY.

elements.content: In addition to the positive influence that incorporating a chromophore into a MOF has on the fluorescence QY and stability, MOFs can often possess permanent porosity. This presents an opportunity to further influence the LMOF emission through the loading of guest molecules into the structure.
elements.clean_text: In addition to the positive influence that incorporating a chromophore into a MOF has on the fluorescence QY and stability, MOFs can often possess permanent porosity. This presents an opportunity to further influence the LMOF emission through the loading of guest molecules into the structure.

elements.content: In order to investigate the influence that potential host–guest interactions could have on the emission from 5, aromatic solvents with varying functional groups were loaded into this LMOF using a solvent-exchange procedure (see S8 and Figure S9). Under 365 nm excitation, the emission from 5 was tunable based on which guest molecule was present ().
elements.clean_text: In order to investigate the influence that potential host-guest interactions could have on the emission from 5, aromatic solvents with varying functional groups were loaded into this LMOF using a solvent-exchange procedure (see S8 and Figure S9). Under 365 nm excitation, the emission from 5 was tunable based on which guest molecule was present ().

elements.content: Overlaid normalized emission spectra for guest-loaded samples of 5. In order of decreasing emission energy, the guest molecules are butylbenzene (violet), 1,2,4-trimethylbenzene (blue), p-chlorotoluene (aqua), p-xylene (light green), bromobenzene (dark green), chlorobenzene (yellow), toluene (orange), and outgassed 5 (red, no guest molecule).
elements.clean_text: 10  Overlaid normalized emission spectra for guest-loaded samples of 5. In order of decreasing emission energy, the guest molecules are butylbenzene (violet), 1,2,4-trimethylbenzene (blue), p-chlorotoluene (aqua), p-xylene (light green), bromobenzene (dark green), chlorobenzene (yellow), toluene (orange), and outgassed 5 (red, no guest molecule).

elements.content: Interestingly, the electron-donating or -withdrawing character of functional groups on the guest molecules had little effect on the observed emission shift; instead, the guest molecule size appears to have had the largest impact. In the presence of butylbenzene and 1,3,5-trimethylbenzene, the emission from 5 was strongly blue-shifted to 488 and 489 nm, respectively. A more moderate blue shift was observed in the presence of p-chlorotoluene and p-xylene, with emissions at 508 and 509 nm, while the smallest blue shift was observed in the presence of bromobenzene, chlorobenzene, and toluene, with emission peaks at 517, 519, and 520 nm. This relationship between the guest size and emission shifting may be related to the closer interactions that are expected between larger guest molecules and the LMOF pore.
elements.clean_text: Interestingly, the electron-donating or -withdrawing character of functional groups on the guest molecules had little effect on the observed emission shift; instead, the guest molecule size appears to have had the largest impact. In the presence of butylbenzene and 1,3,5-trimethylbenzene, the emission from 5 was strongly blue-shifted to 488 and 489 nm, respectively. A more moderate blue shift was observed in the presence of p-chlorotoluene and p-xylene, with emissions at 508 and 509 nm, while the smallest blue shift was observed in the presence of bromobenzene, chlorobenzene, and toluene, with emission peaks at 517, 519, and 520 nm. This relationship between the guest size and emission shifting may be related to the closer interactions that are expected between larger guest molecules and the LMOF pore.

elements.content: Chromophore-based LMOFs present an exciting opportunity to develop high-performance, rare-earth free phosphor materials. Upon immobilization of organic chromophores into a rigid framework, both their luminescence quantum efficiency and thermal stability can be greatly improved. Various LMOF structures can be obtained by incorporating different chromophores, and adjustments to the chromophore emission energy can be achieved through the careful selection of coligands. Additionally, the inherent porosity of the LMOF system presents the opportunity to further tune the phosphor emission through interaction with selected guest molecules.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions and Outlook

Chromophore-based LMOFs present an exciting opportunity to develop high-performance, rare-earth free phosphor materials. Upon immobilization of organic chromophores into a rigid framework, both their luminescence quantum efficiency and thermal stability can be greatly improved. Various LMOF structures can be obtained by incorporating different chromophores, and adjustments to the chromophore emission energy can be achieved through the careful selection of coligands. Additionally, the inherent porosity of the LMOF system presents the opportunity to further tune the phosphor emission through interaction with selected guest molecules.

elements.content: In this Forum Article, we have briefly discussed the process of constructing several highly emissive LMOFs with potential applications as lighting phosphor materials and presented two new isoreticular MOFs with varying luminescence properties. Future work in this area will include more in-depth studies of the fluorescence mechanism in dual-ligand MOFs, as well as an effort to develop LMOFs based on orange- and red-emitting organic chromophores.
elements.clean_text: In this Forum Article, we have briefly discussed the process of constructing several highly emissive LMOFs with potential applications as lighting phosphor materials and presented two new isoreticular MOFs with varying luminescence properties. Future work in this area will include more in-depth studies of the fluorescence mechanism in dual-ligand MOFs, as well as an effort to develop LMOFs based on orange- and red-emitting organic chromophores.

cln_elements.content: (a) Structure of the chromophore tppe. (b) Tetrahedral Zn2+ ion, bpdc coligand in gray, and tppe in gold combining to form the PBU. (c) Structure of a single LMOF-241 framework, with hexagonal channels running along the c axis. (d) Three distinct LMOF-241 frameworks that interpenetrate to form the complete structure. Color key: C, gray or gold; N, blue; O, red; Zn, aqua. Reprinted with permission from ref . Copyright 2015 American Chemical Society.

cln_elements.content: Top: UV–vis absorption of tppe (pink, dotted) and 3 (blue, solid). The inset is a schematic demonstrating the relative positions of the HOMO/LUMO energy levels of tppe, btc, and 3 and the band-gap modulation process. Bottom: Excitation and emission spectra of the tppe chromophore (dotted) and 3 (solid), with emission spectra collected under varying excitation energies. tppe: excitation (pink) and emission under 360 nm (black), 400 nm (red), 420 nm (blue), and 440 nm (green). 3: excitation (blue, left) and emission under 360 nm (black), 400 nm (red), 420 nm (blue, right), and 440 nm (green). Reprinted with permission from ref . Copyright 2014 American Chemical Society.
cln_elements.clean_text: 5  Top: UV-vis absorption of tppe (pink, dotted) and 3 (blue, solid). The inset is a schematic demonstrating the relative positions of the HOMO/LUMO energy levels of tppe, btc, and 3 and the band-gap modulation process. Bottom: Excitation and emission spectra of the tppe chromophore (dotted) and 3 (solid), with emission spectra collected under varying excitation energies. tppe: excitation (pink) and emission under 360 nm (black), 400 nm (red), 420 nm (blue), and 440 nm (green). 3: excitation (blue, left) and emission under 360 nm (black), 400 nm (red), 420 nm (blue, right), and 440 nm (green). Reprinted with permission from ref . Copyright 2014 American Chemical Society.

cln_elements.content: (a) Schematic representations of the PBU (top left), tppe chromophore (top right), SBU (bottom left), and btc ligand (bottom left). (b) Structure of a single net in 3, with large octagonal channels running along the a axis. (c) View along the a axis showing one-dimensional channels in the framework. (d) Two identical frameworks interpenetrating to form the complete structure of 3. Color key: C, gray; N, blue; O, red; Zn, aqua. Reprinted with permission from ref . Copyright 2014 American Chemical Society.

cln_elements.content: Overlaid normalized emission spectra for guest-loaded samples of 5. In order of decreasing emission energy, the guest molecules are butylbenzene (violet), 1,2,4-trimethylbenzene (blue), p-chlorotoluene (aqua), p-xylene (light green), bromobenzene (dark green), chlorobenzene (yellow), toluene (orange), and outgassed 5 (red, no guest molecule).
cln_elements.clean_text: 10  Overlaid normalized emission spectra for guest-loaded samples of 5. In order of decreasing emission energy, the guest molecules are butylbenzene (violet), 1,2,4-trimethylbenzene (blue), p-chlorotoluene (aqua), p-xylene (light green), bromobenzene (dark green), chlorobenzene (yellow), toluene (orange), and outgassed 5 (red, no guest molecule).

metadata.title:
Chromophore-Based Luminescent Metal–Organic Frameworks as
Lighting Phosphors
